title: 111_s3755
content:
The Act is titled the "Fairness in Admiralty and Maritime Law Act" and includes amendments to the Limitation of Shipowners' Liability Act of 1851. The "Fairness in Admiralty and Maritime Law Act" amends the Limitation of Shipowners' Liability Act of 1851. Chapter 305 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to limit the liability of vessel owners for certain claims, debts, or liabilities. The liability of an owner is capped at the value of the vessel and pending freight, with exceptions for claims such as wages, personal injury, wrongful death, and oil drilling or exploration. The "Fairness in Admiralty and Maritime Law Act" amends the Limitation of Shipowners' Liability Act of 1851 by adding an exclusion for claims related to oil drilling or exploration, or the discharge of oil from a vessel or offshore facility. Claims for personal injury or wrongful death are subject to limitations if the vessel was a fishing vessel. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act defines commercial fishing activities and excludes passenger vessels. Section 30511 is amended to address cessation of other actions. Section 30511 of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to state that once an action has been brought under this section and the owner has complied with the requirements, all claims and proceedings against the owner related to the matter in question will cease. SEC. 3. ASSESSMENT OF PUNITIVE DAMAGES IN MARITIME LAW. This section allows for punitive damages to be assessed in civil actions for damages arising from maritime torts without regard to compensatory damages. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO THE DEATH ON THE HIGH SEAS ACT. This section makes amendments to the Death on the High Seas Act. Chapter 303 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to admiralty and nonpecuniary loss in cases of maritime accidents. Additionally, amendments are made to address aviation accidents in maritime law. Amendments are made to Chapter 303 of title 46, United States Code, to define commercial aviation, general aviation, and nonpecuniary damages. Procedures for bringing actions related to these amendments in admiralty are also specified. Amendments to Chapter 303 of title 46, United States Code, redefine aviation and make conforming amendments to section 30307. The amendments made to Chapter 303 of title 46, United States Code redefine aviation and make conforming amendments to section 30307. These changes do not apply to fishing vessels, which are defined as vessels used for charter fishing, commercial fishing, or aiding one or more fishing activities. The amendments to Chapter 303 of title 46, United States Code redefine aviation and make conforming amendments to section 30307. This does not apply to fishing vessels, which are defined as vessels used for charter fishing, commercial fishing, or aiding fishing activities at sea. Passenger vessels are excluded from this definition. SEC. 5. IMPROVEMENTS TO RECOVERY UNDER THE JONES ACT. Amends Section 30104 of title 46, United States Code, allowing seamen injured in the course of employment to bring civil action against the employer. Recovery for loss of care, comfort, and companionship is included for claims related to oil drilling or exploration. 

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this title shall apply to causes of action and claims arising after April 19, 2010, or actions commenced before the date of enactment of this Act that have not been finally adjudicated.
